thread.title: Winter Storm Niko to become a northeast snowstorm: Winter storm warnings issued for Philadelphia, New York City ... - AOL News
thread.title_full: Winter Storm Niko to become a northeast snowstorm: Winter storm warnings issued for Philadelphia, New York City ... - AOL News

title: Winter Storm Niko to become a northeast snowstorm: Winter storm warnings issued for Philadelphia, New York City ... - AOL News
text:
SEE ALL BACK TO SLIDE 
As virtually always is the case, there are uncertainties on the exact track and forward speed of Niko. The latest forecast guidance is suggesting a track favorable for widespread accumulating snow, with the heaviest amounts from eastern Pennsylvania and the New York City Tri-State area into southern New England. 
Here's the timeline and how much snow could fall. 
Wednesday Night Snow spreads from the Ohio Valley and Appalachians into the Northeast. The line separating rain from snow is still uncertain, making the forecast for the transition from rain to snow difficult from far southeast Pennsylvania to Maryland, the Delmarva Peninsula and northern Virginia. At least some snow is most likely overnight north of Interstate 95, from north of Philadelphia to southern New England, including the New York City Tri-State area. Wednesday Night's Forecast, Credit: TWC 
Thursday Snow may linger along the mid-Atlantic coast at least through the morning. Farther north, snow could be heavy at times from eastern Pennsylvania and the New York City Tri-State area into New England. Gusty winds will also be on the increase across parts of the Northeast. Thursday's Forecast, Credit: TWC 
How Much Snow? In general, moderate to locally heavy accumulations of a half-foot or more are possible from eastern Pennsylvania and the New York City Tri-State area into New England. Locally higher snowfall rates could lead to greater amounts in some areas, particularly in southern New England, where up to a foot of snow is not out of the question. Lighter amounts are forecast farther south into the mid-Atlantic region, though some higher terrain locations in the central Appalachians could also see higher totals. The snow will lead to a tricky Thursday morning commute for at least part of the Boston-New York-Philadelphia-Baltimore-Washington D.C. corridor. Flight delays are likely. The Thursday evening commute may be challenging in southeastern New England, including the Boston and Providence metro areas. Some blowing and drifting snow is possible Thursday in southeastern New England if the offshore low strengthens appreciably.
